Can you explain how most leading blockchain networks today were initially decentralized through ICOs or large pre-mines, rather than a fairly launched protocol?

That's not correct. Most leading blockchain networks today were initially centralized through ICOs or large pre-mines, rather than a fairly launched protocol, which is the opposite of what you're saying. This centralization has led to a lack of focus on designing or implementing core protocol primitives, such as currencies or identities, beyond one native currency.

Title: Verus Internet Protocol (VIP) — Provable, Decentralized Cross-chain Communication
Article URL: https://medium.com/veruscoin/verus-internet-protocol-vip-provable-decentralized-cross-chain-communication-8d9414a429c5
Content:Verus Internet Protocol (VIP) — Provable, Decentralized Cross-chain Communication
Written by Mike Toutonghi, lead developer of the Verus Protocol.How it started
Bitcoin proved that decentralized, secure, permissionless and provable agreement on a worldwide blockchain network of participants is possible.
How it’s going
Beyond Bitcoin, most leading blockchain networks today were initially centralized through ICOs or large pre-mines, rather than a fairly launched protocol. In some cases, the ICO or pre-mined share of ownership was further entrenched by switching from proof of work, as a way for anyone to earn, to pure proof of stake, where owning the network currency is required to earn and those with the most earn the most. As part of prioritizing early growth to capture maximum crypto market share, these platforms generally abdicated the hard work of designing or implementing core protocol primitives, such as currencies or identities, beyond one native currency, as originally conceived in Bitcoin.
Instead, the popular VM model of many blockchains today, which generally provide a shared “computer” or VM on top of a decentralized blockchain, leaves building critical primitives as someone else’s problem, usually companies and app designers, basically writing centralized apps. Instead of a secure set of underlying rules for currencies, we get best practices and the evolutionary legacy of thousands of “dApps”, which ironically, are mostly just partial or full re-implementations of the secure primitives missing in the consensus-based L1 protocols themselves.
As a result of the focus on pumping and market capture vs. evolving what we could learn from
./raw_text_input_medium/Verus Internet Protocol (VIP) — Provable, Decentralized Cross-chain Communication-2023-08-24 10:11:22
How do the popular VM models of many blockchains today provide a secure set of underlying rules for currencies?

The popular VM models of many blockchains today do not provide a secure set of underlying rules for currencies. Instead, they leave building critical primitives as someone else's problem, usually companies and app designers, which often results in centralized apps. This is in contrast to a secure set of underlying rules for currencies, which is what is needed.

Title: Verus Internet Protocol (VIP) — Provable, Decentralized Cross-chain Communication

./raw_text_input_medium/Verus Internet Protocol (VIP) — Provable, Decentralized Cross-chain Communication-2023-08-24 10:11:22
How has the focus on developing blockchain protocols impacted the creation of secure primitives in these networks?

The focus has been on pumping and market capture, rather than evolving what can be learned from Bitcoin and other pioneering blockchain networks. As a result, many blockchain networks have not developed secure primitives, but instead have relied on best practices and the evolutionary legacy of thousands of "dApps", which are often just partial or full re-implementations of the secure primitives missing in the consensus-based L1 protocols themselves.
